--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Karl Lewin <lewinke67@y...> wrote:
> What is the stopping condition for the XOR experiment
> as reported in the "Evolving Neural Networks through
> Augmenting Topologies" paper?  In the code there
> appears to be several different stopping conditions 
> some of which are commented out.  I'm trying to see if
> my implementation at least produces comparable 
> results.  
> 
> If the condition is:
> 
> output for [0,0] < 0.5
> output for [1,0] >= 0.5
> output for [0,1] >= 0.5
> output for [1,1] < 0.5
> 

I believe that's the condition I used, yes.

> Then I am getting reasonably comparable results.  I 
> haven't collected statistics yet but it seems to 
> evolve a successful net in 15-40 generations 
> (population size 100) on average.
> 

Yeah that sounds about right.

> I'm almost positvie I haven't implemented all the 
> different routines/options for generating a new 
> population.  Am I cheating by doing (approximately) 
> this:
> 

Just to make sure I'm following, I think you mean generating the 
next generation (new population usually implies the start of a run 
only).

> 0. Number of children for each species determined by 
> species average fitness
> 
> 1. Direct copy species champ for any species that is
> designated to get at least 1 child.
> 

Actually I had it only do this for species designated to
get at least (I think) 5 children.  The reason is that a
species that is going to have very few children needs room
for diversity or else it will never change.

> 2.  70% chance for child by crossover of parents 
> selected from species.  Selection is biased by 
> individual fitness within species.  Weights can be
> perturbed by a small amount
> 
> 3. 3% chance for child created adding node by 
> mutation. Selection of individual to mutate is biased 
> by individual fitness within species
> 
> 4. 4% chance for child created adding connection by 
> mutation. Selection of individual to mutate is biased 
> by individual fitness within species
> 

I believe it was 5% but no big deal.

Note that "selection of individuals to mutate" and "selection of 
individuals to mate" is the same thing.  First it 
selects "individuals to reproduce" and then it decides during 
reproduction whether to mate or mutate them.

> After I feel a little more comfortable with my code,
> I'll make it available if anyone wants.  Its fairly slow.
> 
> 

It sounds like you've got more or less the right setup.   Of course 
there are likely odds and ends that are bit different in our 
implementations, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.  I think it 
would be great to make it available if you feel comfortable it's 
actually working properly.  Does it have any visualization or data 
collection to check what happens over the course of a run?

ken
